overview: From 2025-10-19 to 2025-10-26, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 67 new PRs (51 merged), 15 new issues, and 62 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Update OPCMStandardValidator to handle new dispute game contracts
topIssues.author: mbaxter
topIssues.body:
## Description

The `OPContractsManagerStandardValidator` currently pulls a lot of data from the dispute game implementations set in the `DisputeGameFactory`.  For version 2 of these contracts, some of this data is no longer accessible on the implementation.  We'll need to find a way to continue validating the dispute game config.  We should be able to just inspect the `DisputeGameFactory.gameArgs` data to validate the parameters that are no longer stored on the implementation.

topIssues.title: kurtosis: Ability to use local op-geth build
topIssues.author: sebastianst
topIssues.body:
It would be great to be able to tell kurtosis to use a local op-geth build (e.g. the one linked to in `go.mod`), on-demand building an op-geth Docker image.

Kurtosis currently just uses the optimism-package op-geth pinned version, which is the latest op-geth release. This means we cannot test local op-geth modifications in Kurtosis.

topIssues.title: Prevent setting implementation for reserved game types in DisputeGameFactory
topIssues.author: ajsutton
topIssues.body: As per https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/17832#discussion_r2429556986 `DisputeGameFacotry.setImplementation` should be what enforces that games can't be created with the reserved game type.

topIssues.title: [DA Footprint Limit] Investigate why block right after genesis still has 0 gas scalar
topIssues.author: sebastianst
topIssues.body: In current tests, block 1 after genesis still has a 0 gas scalar. But it should have the default scalar already. Current tests skip the first block because of this.

topIssues.title: Improve `op-up` so it can serve as a sysgo runner during development
topIssues.author: sebastianst
topIssues.body:
Since we're deprecating Kurtosis, we need a new tool for developers to quickly spin up a local devnet. The current candidate for this is `op-up`, but probably a few modifications are necessary to make it feasible for local development.

- We want to have a few presets and/or flags/env-vars so that individual components can be turned on or off (e.g. batcher, proposer, challenger, number of validators, op-reth/geth, ...)
- We want to directly spin up the in-memory sysgo-based components without the need to build a Docker container
    - We probably want to assign a few static ports (optionally configurable) so developers can reliably find the same components at the same ports. Those could be different than the standard ports.
- Related: https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17941

topPRs.title: Add safe compatibility tests
topPRs.author: JosepBove
topPRs.body: Adds a base contract to inherit when doing safe compatibility tests. It has 2 helper functions to do the testing the Verbose one is superchain-ops style to use while developing to see where everything is failing, the one that does not have Verbose on it is the one expected on tests but will fail on the first encountered revert.

topPRs.title: op-challenger: Support retrieving the oracle and prestate via game args.
topPRs.author: ajsutton
topPRs.body:
**Description**

The implementation contract doesn't always have the values embedded. It automatically switches between game args and reading from the implementation, as well as detecting versions that don't yet support game args for backwards compatibility.

The `GetGameImpl` method is now internal to `DisputeGameFactory` to ensure that nothing is grabbing the game implementation and depending on its behaviour. `DisputeGameFactory` exposes methods to get the VM or Prestate in a way that's compatible with game args.

**Tests**

Updated tests. Smoke test that detected this is now enabled.


**Metadata**

fixes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17810

topPRs.title: proofs: Migrate SuperFaultDisputeGame to creator pattern
topPRs.author: Inphi
topPRs.body:
This patch only implements the necessary OPCM functions to support the `SuperFaultDisputeGame`  for e2e testing.
Notably, `addGameType`, `updatePrestate`, and `deploy` have yet to be fully migrated to use v2 games. This is OK for the time being since we don't interact with those functions for super dispute games.

part of https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17972

topPRs.title: opcm: Update upgrade method for disputegame-v2
topPRs.author: Inphi
topPRs.body:
Adds support for creator pattern when upgrading dispute game implementations via OPCM.

fixes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17258

completedItems.title: Upgrade Gnosis Safe libs to 1.4.1
completedItems.body:
The monorepo version of the gnosis safe libs is 1.3.0, which is several breaking versions behind.

This is a problem because we can't test SaferSafes for the safe versions that would be deployed today, and forces us to keep deploying 1.3.

completedItems.title: ci: Clean up op-deployer caches
completedItems.body: We keep running into issues where OPD caches are not properly cleaned up in tests. This adds a stopgap that cleans them up after every test to prevent disk usage exploding on our self-hosted runners.

completedItems.title: op-deployer: run TestCLIBootrap subtests with isolated anvil env
completedItems.body: The `TestCLIBootstrap` tests have been flagged as flakey by circleci. To address the flakiness, this pr creates a fresh/isolated anvil env to run each subtest instead of using a shared anvil env for all tests.

completedItems.title: SaferSafes: Fix version checks
completedItems.body:
Draft PR to remove the extraneous diff from #17997. 

I created this using the `lazygit` TUI to drop a merge commit. The cli command to do so would be something like `git rebase --interactive --rebase-merges 1b31ed3a0d899b899846342bfb7688

completedItems.title: fix: stop graphite complaining about versions
Move state changes to checkTransaction
completedItems.body: The state changes in `checkAfterExecution` break the CEI pattern and introduces unneeded complexity. Moving them to `checkTransaction` achieves the same end.
